title: Child-Pugh Score for Cirrhosis Mortality
description: Estimates severity of cirrhosis and prognosis in patients with chronic liver disease

ranges.interpretation: Excellent operative risk. One-year survival ~100%, two-year survival ~85%. Suitable for major surgery. Good candidates for liver resection.
Good operative risk. One-year survival ~80%, two-year survival ~60%. Consider for surgery with caution. May require liver transplant evaluation.
Poor operative risk. One-year survival ~45%, two-year survival ~35%. High surgical mortality. Priority candidates for liver transplantation.

references: Child CG, Turcotte JG. Surgery and portal hypertension. In: The liver and portal hypertension. Edited by CG Child. Philadelphia: Saunders 1964:50-64.
Pugh RN, Murray-Lyon IM, Dawson JL, Pietroni MC, Williams R. Transection of the oesophagus for bleeding oesophageal varices. Br J Surg. 1973 Aug;60(8):646-9.
Durand F, Valla D. Assessment of prognosis of cirrhosis. Semin Liver Dis. 2008 Feb;28(1):110-22.
formula: Score = Bilirubin points + Albumin points + INR points + Ascites points + Encephalopathy points
notes: Originally developed to predict mortality during portacaval shunt surgery
Widely used to assess prognosis in cirrhotic patients
MELD and MELD-Na scores now preferred for liver transplant allocation
Should be reassessed if clinical condition changes
Each parameter scored 1-3 points based on severity
